G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The Plaintiff, Rachel Thompson, respectfully moves this Honorable Court, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, to modify the existing custody order entered by this Court on May 15, 2020.

G.L. c. 209C.proposition: This Honorable Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C and G.L. c. 208, § 28, as this case pertains to the care, custody, and welfare of the parties' minor children, who reside in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, a custody order may be modified when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and the modification is in the best interests of the children.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.proposition: A parent’s living arrangement and the presence of individuals who may jeopardize a child's safety are critical factors in determining the best interests of the children. See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (2006); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.support_reasoning: The opinion frames the removal analysis entirely around the children’s best interests and explicitly lists as a key factor “potential misconduct by other siblings in the mother’s household” weighing against increased time in that household. The trial judge’s best-interests findings—approved by the SJC—stress the impact of the mother’s proposed living arrangement (crowded multichild home, move to grandparents’ house) and the presence of a step-sibling accused of inappropriate touching. This directly treats living arrangements and the presence of individuals who may jeopardize safety as critical best-interests considerations.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the mother’s children claimed one of them was inappropriately touched by the son of the mother’s new husband. … The judge…determined that removal to New Hampshire…was not in the best interests of the children… The judge found that Chelmsford schools were preferable…; that uprooting the children would be detrimental…; that the move would cause a reduction of the father’s parenting time…; that misconduct allegations against a step-sibling weighed against increased time in the mother’s household… From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.proposition: A parent’s living arrangement and the presence of individuals who may jeopardize a child's safety are critical factors in determining the best interests of the children. See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (2006); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss best-interests custody factors, including stability of the home, work schedule, sibling relationships, and a parent’s efforts to undermine the child’s relationship with the other parent. However, it does not address a parent’s *living arrangement* or the *presence of individuals who may jeopardize a child’s safety* as factors; those concepts do not appear in the court’s analysis. Thus, this case does not support the specific proposition for which it is cited, even though it is about best-interests determinations generally.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.relevant_excerpt: “However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.” (463 Mass. at 494-95).

*Carey v. Carey*, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 186,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that the safety and well-being of minor children take precedence in custody matters. See *Carey v. Carey*, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 186, 191 (1998); *Hemmings v. Hemmings*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 220, 221 (1988).
*Carey v. Carey*, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 186,.support_reasoning: The provided text is not Carey v. Carey at all, but Kurker v. Hill (Kurker v. Hill & others), a closely held corporation/attorney-liability case dealing with fiduciary duties, civil conspiracy, and related business torts. It does not concern child custody or the relative priority of minor children’s safety and well-being. Because the opinion excerpt neither addresses family law nor custody standards, it cannot support the proposition about custody principles in Massachusetts.

*Hemmings v. Hemmings*, 26 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that the safety and well-being of minor children take precedence in custody matters. See *Carey v. Carey*, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 186, 191 (1998); *Hemmings v. Hemmings*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 220, 221 (1988).
*Hemmings v. Hemmings*, 26 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: This is a criminal drug trafficking appeal that deals with burden-shifting jury instructions and ineffective assistance of counsel. It does not involve custody, family law, or any discussion of the safety and well-being of minor children, nor does it articulate any principle about the precedence of children’s welfare in custody matters. The citation to Hemmings v. Hemmings for that proposition is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by this opinion.
*Hemmings v. Hemmings*, 26 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: After a Superior Court jury trial, the defendant was convicted of trafficking in heroin... On appeal, the defendant claims that (1) the jury instructions impermissibly shifted to her the burden of disproving certain elements of the crime and (2) one misstatement by defense counsel in closing argument amounted to ineffective assistance of counsel. We affirm.

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The presence of a violent individual in the children’s living environment is a relevant factor in assessing the appropriateness of a custody arrangement. See *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261 (2001).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is an extensive discussion of modification of custody and parental relocation, but it does not discuss the presence of a violent individual in the children’s environment or treat such a factor as relevant to custody. The court’s analysis focuses on work schedules, extended family, relocation distance, and the custodial parent’s and child’s quality of life, not on violence or dangerous third parties. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements… To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker. The probate judge took note of the fact that both parents love the child, and that ‘both parents have safe and secure homes. . . . The child is happy in each party’s home.’”

*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 614.proposition: The Court has authority to impose supervised visitation or other restrictions when the conduct or associations of a parent endanger the welfare of the children. See *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 614 (1987).
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 614.support_reasoning: The opinion in Bak v. Bak deals extensively with custody, jurisdiction, and best-interests analysis, but it does not discuss supervised visitation or imposing specific visitation restrictions based on a parent’s conduct or associations. The only portion touching visitation is the court’s approval of ‘reasonably liberal visitation rights’ and an intention to coordinate with the German court, not to restrict visitation due to endangerment. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about supervised or restricted visitation based on endangerment to the children.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 614.relevant_excerpt: “Finally, we note the judge’s stated intention of making contact with his counterpart in the Bielefeld Family Court to construct a joint order on visitation. It is the judge’s laudable desire that Anthony have reasonably liberal visitation rights which may be exercised both in Germany and this country. We hope that an order with complementary terms can be arranged by the two courts which will allow both parents maximum time with their children in a cooperative effort to rear them.”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 548.proposition: An argument involving the Defendant and his partner that led to police intervention triggers the Court’s obligation to assess potential harm to the children and modify orders accordingly under *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 548 (2010).
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 548.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is about statutory interpretation of the Massachusetts paternity statute and the limits on a judge’s authority to order a relocating, sole-legal parent to return to Massachusetts. It does not discuss any argument between a defendant and partner, police intervention, or an ensuing obligation of the court to assess harm to children and modify orders. The core holding concerns relocation, parental rights, and stability, not police-involved domestic incidents triggering a duty to reassess child safety or modify orders.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 548.relevant_excerpt: “The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. … As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is ‘free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].’ … After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart … and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a)….”

*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598, 601.proposition: Courts must weigh the probable harm to the children against the parent's right to visitation when those rights conflict. See *Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598, 601 (1976); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 400 (1981).
*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598, 601.support_reasoning: The opinion in Gilmore focuses on procedural fairness in custody determinations, specifically the right to cross-examine a guardian ad litem whose report is relied on, and reiterates that custody decisions are governed by the best interests of the child. It does not address or articulate any balancing test between probable harm to the children and a parent’s right to visitation. Therefore, citing Gilmore for the specific proposition that courts must weigh probable harm to the children against the parent's visitation rights is inaccurate.
*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598, 601.relevant_excerpt: “We are mindful of the court’s need for assistance in arriving at a just resolution of custody cases. There is no question that court-appointed investigators can help a judge to determine what is in the best interests of a child, ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided.’ Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930). … In a custody proceeding, a judge makes a determination as to what is in the best interests of the child on the basis of facts presented at trial as well as facts gathered by the court-appointed investigators.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: Courts must weigh the probable harm to the children against the parent's right to visitation when those rights conflict. See *Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598, 601 (1976); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 400 (1981).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses visitation in section 3 and explicitly states that promoting the children’s best interests may require limiting a parent’s liberties when the parents are in conflict, citing Felton and DiRusso. This reflects a balancing of the children’s welfare (probable harm or risk to them) against the parent’s visitation interests, consistent with the proposition that courts must weigh the harm to children against parental visitation rights when those interests conflict.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order. … ‘[T]he ‘best interests’ of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 233.”

*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.proposition: In light of the Defendant’s decision to reside with an individual whose conduct endangers the children, modification of the existing custody order is warranted to address this material change in circumstances. See *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 819 (1981); *Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658 (2002).
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.support_reasoning: Hale v. Hale concerns a custodial parent’s request to remove children from Massachusetts and articulates the best-interests standard and the need to consider the custodial parent’s well-being in removal decisions. It does not address modification of custody based on a noncustodial or custodial parent residing with someone whose conduct endangers the children, nor does it discuss a ‘material change in circumstances’ of that kind. Using Hale for the proposition that cohabitation with a dangerous individual warrants modification of custody therefore overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.relevant_excerpt: “The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent, and the determination, therefore, requires that the interests of the mother also be taken into account. … We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests.”

*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658 (20.proposition: In light of the Defendant’s decision to reside with an individual whose conduct endangers the children, modification of the existing custody order is warranted to address this material change in circumstances. See *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 819 (1981); *Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658 (2002).
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658 (20.support_reasoning: Blixt v. Blixt concerns the constitutionality and construction of the Massachusetts grandparent visitation statute and the standards (presumption of parental fitness, harm requirement) governing third‑party visitation. It does not address custody modification standards, parental decisions to reside with dangerous individuals, or what constitutes a material change in circumstances for custody purposes. Citing Blixt for the proposition that a parent’s cohabitation with a dangerous person warrants custody modification misstates the scope and subject of the decision.
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 658 (20.relevant_excerpt: “To obtain visitation, the grandparents must rebut the presumption. The burden of proof will lie with them to establish, by a preponderance of the credible evidence, that a decision by the judge to deny visitation is not in the best interests of the child. More specifically, to succeed, the grandparents must allege and prove that the failure to grant visitation will cause the child significant harm by adversely affecting the child’s health, safety, or welfare.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 598.proposition: This case plainly involves a substantial risk of harm to the children, requiring immediate intervention of this Honorable Court under its broad equitable authority to protect the welfare of minors. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 598 (1996); *Adoption of Nancy*, 443 Mass. 512, 515 (2005).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 598.support_reasoning: The case concerns standards for custody determinations in the presence of domestic violence and the need for explicit findings on the effect of that violence on the child. It does not invoke or discuss the Supreme Judicial Court’s broad equitable authority, emergency or immediate intervention, or a standard of “substantial risk of harm” triggering such intervention. Instead, it remands for further findings within the ordinary custody framework, so it does not provide authority for the quoted proposition about immediate equitable intervention by the court.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 598.relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Adoption of Nancy*, 443 Mass. 512, 515.proposition: This case plainly involves a substantial risk of harm to the children, requiring immediate intervention of this Honorable Court under its broad equitable authority to protect the welfare of minors. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 598 (1996); *Adoption of Nancy*, 443 Mass. 512, 515 (2005).
*Adoption of Nancy*, 443 Mass. 512, 515.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that Adoption of Nancy is authority for immediate intervention under a court’s broad equitable power to protect minors from a substantial risk of harm. Adoption of Nancy instead concerns statutory termination of parental rights under G.L. c. 210 and c. 119, applying the ‘best interests’ and parental unfitness framework after lengthy care-and-protection proceedings. The opinion does not discuss or invoke any separate, broad equitable authority for emergency or immediate intervention by an appellate court; it addresses when termination may be ordered and how children’s wishes factor into that decision.
*Adoption of Nancy*, 443 Mass. 512, 515.relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether to dispense with parental consent to adoption, a judge must ‘evaluate whether the [parent is] able to assume the duties and responsibilities required of a parent and whether dispensing with the need for parental consent will be in the best interests of the children.’ … After ascertaining unfitness, the judge must determine whether the parent’s unfitness is such that it would be in the child’s best interests to end all legal relations between parent and child.”
